issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: Signifies completion of tasks, info requests, etc.
resolution.name: Completed

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description: Instead of "no data available" message, should show updated message in comments below.
fields.summary: ELB CW charts should display more informative message for empty data set

comments.body:
[~jloza]: The only way to force NVD3 (our charting library) to display an empty chart is to pass it an empty list within an empty list, as documented at http://stackoverflow.com/questions/17458236/nvd3-showing-empty-chart-instead-of-nodata-message

The charts seem busted even with that workaround (see attached screenshot).  I'll continue to fiddle with it, but we may be stuck with the "No data available" message for 4.2.  We should look at alternate charting libraries (e.g. c3js.org) for the 4.3 release, and I'll add these notes to our 4.3 summit doc.

based on phone call, we're trying to see if we can customize the messaging in 4.2 to say "No data available until this load balancer receives traffic." This should ease confusion in 4.2 and we can look at different charting libraries in 4.3 when we have more time.
The "no data" message can easily be customized based on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/23582292/custom-no-data-label-in-nvd3-scatter-chart

[~jloza]: Grr, updating the "no data" text is more painful than I expected due to SVG's poor text handling capabilities.  Seems we can't add line breaks to SVG text without jumping through hoops -- will continue to fiddle.  Screenshot attached.

[~jloza]: Since we can't add line breaks to the "no data" text in our charts, I tried a shorter message, "ELB has not received traffic yet", which seems to fit well in the chart container. Screenshot attached -- lemme know what you think?

[~kgill], note that if there are no instances registered to the ELB, the healthy and unhealthy hosts metrics will return empty data sets. So, we should have a different message for those two, indicating "No data available until instances are registered with this load balancer."
[~jloza]: Copy on the empty data message for healthy/unhealthy hosts, but we'll need a shorter message since we can't add line-breaks to text in SVG (see my prior comment).
PR at https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/1556
Thanks, [~kgill]! UX review passed, ready for code review.

[~jloza]: I tested the Instance Monitoring page and realized we'll need to add an empty data message there as well.  The improved empty message handling affects all charts across the console, so I set the generic default empty message for the instance charts to "No data available for this instance."  Let me know if you want to tweak it or if specific charts should have a distinct message.

Hi [~kgill], dang, I was hoping we wouldn't have to do an empty message for instance charts. I've never seen those empty. Seems like they would only be empty if CW hasn't been enabled long enough to gather the first data set. 

If that's correct, then the message for instances should read "CloudWatch data for this instance is not available yet. Please wait five minutes, then refresh your view." Does that fit OK?
[~jloza]: The charts don't seem to return data when an instance isn't running, so I guess we can't assume waiting five minutes will fix the problem.  Thoughts?

[~jloza]: I should clarify the lack of charting data for stopped instances.  Let's say an instance has been running for a few days but has been stopped 7 hours ago.  CloudWatch won't gather metrics for that instance for the past seven hours, so when the Instance Monitoring page is opened, no data will be returned since the duration defaults to the past hour.  However, there will be data if the duration is increased beyond 6 hours, so perhaps the message should be something along the lines of.. "No data available for this instance for the selected duration." ?

If the instance is stopped we should format the message similarly to when monitoring is turned off (show it in place of the tiles, no tiles at all), and say "Data is not collected for stopped instances. Start your instance to resume data collection, or try showing data for a longer time period to see data from before your instance was stopped."

[~jloza]: Seems our empty chart message for ELB 4xx and 5xx counts is somewhat misleading, since those can be empty even when an ELB has received traffic.  Screenshot attached (elb-charts-misleading-empty-message.png).
[~kgill] [~spark], if the load balancer is receiving traffic, should those sum error counts report 0 instead of empty set? I would think so, from a user's POV...
[~jloza][~kgill] Just checked with ELB and they have empty set for those metrics.

[~kgill] I can't see from the screengrab but what is happening with HTTP 2xxx and 4xxx that we display charts for those and not the other sum error counts? We really should be displaying 0s for those, since that is the actual error count if the load balancer is receiving traffic.
[~jloza]: Only the Sum HTTP 4xxs is displaying data, screenshot updated.  Note this is on AWS.  I'll try on Euca as well.
[~kgill] Hm weird, 2 and 4 were showing data before. This is super terrible UX, we really should be displaying 0s for these. Can you translate NaN to 0 somehow?
[~jloza]: I agree this isn't ideal UX, but we can't display an empty chart (or easily pad with zeros) w/o switching our charting library (per our earlier conversation).

[~jloza]: I've attached a screenshot of the charts for an Euca ELB.  I threw a bunch of load at the ELB via ApacheBench and was able to trigger some ELB 4xxs and 5xxs.

I'm going to fiddle with adding a zero value for the ELB charts that we feel should display zero values (e.g. the 2xx, 3xx, 4xx and 5xx counts).  Will keep you posted.

[~jloza]: I figured out a way to add zero values for ELB charts that should have them rather than the "no data" message.

I also added the appropriate messaging w.r.t. data collection for stopped instances, but I opted to display the chart placeholders since we can't determine until all the charts are loaded if the charts are empty, and hiding those chart boxes after the lazy-loaded calls complete is fairly jarring.  Hopefully that's clear, but we can discuss if necessary next week.

Oh, and if you want to tweak which charts display 0 instead of an empty message, add the metric to the vm.displayZeroChartMetrics list in eucaconsole/static/js/pages/cloudwatch_charts.js (it's around line 40) in the GUi-1971 branch.
Looks good, [~kgill]...UX review passed, ready for code review.
